raw_text:
Chancellor rallies Labour voters
 
 Gordon Brown has issued a rallying cry, telling supporters the "stakes are too high" to stay at home or protest vote in the forthcoming general election.
 
 The chancellor said the vote - expected to fall on 5 May - will give a "clear and fundamental" choice between Labour investment and Conservative cuts. Speaking at Labour's spring conference in Gateshead, Mr Brown claimed the NHS was not safe in Conservative hands. He said Tory plans to cut £35bn tax would "cut deep into public service".
 
 To a packed audience at Gateshead's Sage Centre, the chancellor said the cuts proposed by shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin were the equivalent of sacking every teacher, GP and nurse in the country, he told activists. Laying into the Conservative's record in government he said: "I give you this promise - with Labour, Britain will never return to the mistakes of ERM and 10% inflation, 15% interest rates, £3bn in lost reserves, 250,000 repossessed, one million in negative equity and three million unemployed. "Never again Tory boom and bust.
 
 "This will be the central dividing line at the election, between a Conservative Party taking Britain back and planning deep cuts of £35bn in our services, and a Labour government taking Britain forward, which on a platform of stability will reform and renew our hospitals, schools and public services and, I am proud to say, spend by 2008 £60bn more." Turning to the economy, the chancellor pledged to continue economic stability and growth in a third term in power.
 
 He said after seven years Labour had transformed from a party not trusted with the economy to "the only party trusted with the economy". It was now a "party not just of employees, but of employers and managers", he said. In the speech - which prompted a standing ovation from an audience clearly "warm" to Mr Brown - he also promised to end teenage unemployment within the next five years. He also highlighted plans for 100% debt relief for the world's poorest countries, a national minimum wage for 16 and 17-year-olds and the creation of a network of children's centres and flexibility in maternity leave. The prime minister is to take part later on Saturday in an interactive question and answer session, fielding queries sent in by e-mail, text message and telephone as part of Labour's attempt to engage the public in their campaign.
llama3.2:1b: Gordon Brown has rallied Labour voters with a speech at its spring conference, saying that staying home or protesting would be too high a price to pay for the upcoming general election.
He accused the Conservatives of planning deep cuts to services and vowed that Labour will take Britain forward on stability and reform.
llama3.2:3b: Gordon Brown told Labour supporters that the general election stakes are too high to stay home or protest vote, promising a clear choice between investing in the NHS and making deep cuts under the Conservatives.
He claimed Conservative plans would "cut deep into public service" and vowed to reform and renew public services if elected, while also pledging economic stability and growth.
gemma2:2b: Gordon Brown urged voters to participate in the upcoming election, emphasizing a choice between Labour investment and Conservative cuts.
He highlighted potential NHS danger under Tories and presented Labour's promises for increased public services and economic stability.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Prime Minister calls for Labour supporters to stay home or protest votes at the general election.
Chancellor Gordon Brown suggests that the vote will give a clear choice between Labour investment and Conservative cuts, with Tory plans to cut £35bn affecting the NHS and public service.
Mr Brown pledges that Britain "never again" took back the mistakes of ERM, 10% inflation, etc.
Labour must take Britain forward on services, but not by cutting in the economy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Gordon Brown rallies Labour voters by highlighting NHS safety concerns over Conservative plans for £35bn tax cuts and pledging stability and economic growth under a Labour government.
He promises to improve hospitals, schools, and public services while also committing to end teenage unemployment and provide 100% debt relief for the world's poorest countries.
qwen2.5:3b: Chancellor Brown rallies Labour voters ahead of the 5 May general election, emphasizing a stark choice between Labour's investment-led policies and Conservative austerity measures.
He highlighted concerns about NHS safety under Conservatives and criticized Tory plans for deep cuts to services like education and healthcare.

Brown promised continued economic stability and growth in a third term, as well as commitments such as ending teenage unemployment within five years, 100% debt relief for poor countries, and the creation of children's centers.
He also encouraged direct public engagement through interactive sessions with voters.
opencoder:1.5b: The chancellor has raged with supporters, expected to vote clear or forward, but also promised a "cut deep into public service".
The economy is transforming with increased employment, unemployment rates are reducing, and debt levels are being cut.
The National Minimum Wage has also been extended for those aged 16 and 17.
A National Network of Children's Centres will be established, along with the creation of flexible maternity leave.
The prime minister will participate on Saturday in a session for engaging the public.
smollm:1.7b: The summary should be: Chancellor rallies Labour voters to give them a clear choice between Labour investment and Conservative cuts.

The chancellor told supporters that the stakes are too high to stay at home or protest vote in the forthcoming general election, and promised to take Britain forward by investing in our hospitals, schools and public services and spending £60bn more on these areas over five years.
He also said he would end unemployment within the next five years and promise a national minimum wage for the world's poorest countries.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Gordon Brown has united Labour supporters with a rally that demands an "absolute choice" between Labour investment and Conservative cuts for the upcoming general election on May 5.
He warns that the vote will determine whether the NHS remains safe under Conservative control or see£35bn in cuts, which would profoundly affect public services.
The election will split votes on stability versus deep cuts.

Labour aims to transform into the only party trusted with the economy, while the Conservative record includes concerns about 10% inflation, £3bn lost reserves, and significant social issues like unemployment among young people.
Brown also aims to offer 100% debt relief, a minimum wage, and expanded maternity leave.
tinyllama:1.1b: In the latest political news, Prime Minister Gordon Brown has declared that the general election is set to give a "clear and fundamental" choice between investment in public services and cuts by the Conservatives.

Addressing a packed audience at Gateshead's Sage Centre during Labour's spring conference, Brown urged voters to choose between stability under his leadership and deep cuts that would harm millions of people.
The speech saw Brown highlight plans to end teenage unequalities within five years as well as reducing the national minimum wage for 16- and 17-year-olds to 80% of its level in Denmark.
He also promised to launch a network of children's centres and flexible maternity leave, with access for 100% debt relief for low-income countries by the next five years.

In addition, Brown highlighted plans for 100% debt relief for world's poorest countries and the creation of a network of children's centres and flexible maternity leave as part of his aim to engage the public in his campaign.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In this text, we learn about the Labour Party's plan for the upcoming general election by discussing key points made by Chancellor Gordon Brown.
The government is expected to make significant cuts to public services, including health care, education, and social welfare, in order to balance the budget.
The Labour Party aims to take Britain back by investing heavily in infrastructure and employment opportunities.
Brown criticized the Conservatives for their record on public services, comparing them to "sacking every teacher, GP, and nurse" in the UK.
Brown announced that he will not seek re-election as Labour Party leader, effectively ending any possibility of a coalition government with the Conservatives.
Brown also pledged to spend £60 billion more on public services than his predecessors, promising to deliver "the most ambitious programme in decades."
phi:2.7b: Gordon Brown urges Labour voters not to stay at home or vote for Conservative party in upcoming general election.
He warns that the vote will give a clear choice between Labour investment and Conservative cuts.
Brown also claims that the NHS is safe with Labour, while Tory plans would cut deep into public services.
The chancellor compares the Tory's record in government to sacking every teacher, GP and nurse in Britain.
In a speech at Labour' s spring conference, he promises not to repeat the mistakes of the past and vows to spend £60bn more on public services under a third term in power.

Brown also pledges to continue economic stability and growth, as well as ending teenage unemployment within five years, providing debt relief for poor countries, introducing a national minimum wage, creating children' s centres, and offering flexibility in maternity leave.
Prime minister David Cameron is participating in an interactive question and answer session later on Saturday.
orca-mini:3b: Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the British government, urged Labour voters to turn out in the upcoming general election and cast their vote for his party.
He claimed that the stakes were too high to not vote and that the Conservative Party's plans to cut £35 billion from the tax would have a severe impact on public services such as the NHS.
He also promised to continue economic stability and growth during Labour's third term in power.
hermes3:3b: Chancellor Brown calls Labour voters to oppose Conservative cuts, arguing stakes are high for NHS safety and economic stability during upcoming general election.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown urged Labour voters not to stay at home or protest vote in the upcoming general election, stating that the vote on May 5th will provide a clear choice between investing in Labour and cutting under Conservatives.
He emphasized that the NHS would not be safe under Conservative plans to cut £35bn tax, comparing their proposed cuts to sacking teachers, GPs, and nurses.

Brown promised stability, growth, and reform of hospitals, schools, and public services if his party is elected, while also outlining plans for ending teenage unemployment, debt relief for poorest countries, a national minimum wage for 16 and 17-year-olds, and increased flexibility in maternity leave.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Gordon Brown urged Labour supporters to vote in the upcoming general election, warning that the stakes were too high for abstention or protest votes.

Speaking at Labour's spring conference, he framed the election as a choice between Labour's investment in public services and Conservative cuts, criticizing Tory plans to reduce taxes by £35bn, which he claimed would harm essential services.
He attacked the Conservatives' economic record, vowing that Labour would not return to past financial instability.

Brown pledged continued economic stability, job creation, and social reforms, including ending teenage unemployment, providing 100% debt relief for the world's poorest countries, introducing a minimum wage for 16- and 17-year-olds, and expanding maternity leave and children's centers.
His speech received a standing ovation, and Prime Minister Tony Blair was set to engage with the public in a Q&A session later.
stablelm2:1.6b: Chancellor Brown rallies Labour voters, stating that the general election will offer a "clear and fundamental" choice between Labour investment and Conservative cuts.
He promises to ensure safety for the NHS under his leadership compared to Tory plans for £50bn in tax cuts.
Brown accuses Conservatives of sacking every teacher, GP, and nurse in the UK and warns against returning to mistakes like ERM and inflation.
A packed audience responded positively to his speech at Labour's conference in Gateshead, with promises of continued economic stability and growth in a third term for Labour.
He also pledges to end teenage unemployment within five years and highlights plans for £8bn more spending on hospitals, schools, and public services.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Chancellor Gordon Brown, speaking at Labour's spring conference in Gateshead, emphasized the importance of voting in the upcoming general election on May 5.

He portrayed the vote as a choice between Labour's investment and Conservative cuts, asserting that Tory plans to reduce tax by £35 billion would disproportionately affect public services like teachers, GPs, and nurses.
Brown promised to avoid past economic pitfalls like ERM, high inflation, and large unemployment rates under a Conservative government.
Instead, he pledged continued economic stability and growth during Labour's third term in power.

He highlighted Labour's transformation from an economically untrusted party to one trusted with the economy, and future plans such as ending teenage unemployment within five years, providing 100% debt relief for poor countries, implementing a national minimum wage for young adults, and establishing children's centers.
The prime minister will later engage in an interactive question-and-answer session to further connect with the public during Labour's campaign.
